Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency obligation under IRPA: 730-day rule (minimum 730 days in Canada over a period)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Nekoie spent only 331 days in Canada during a 730-day period, citing business closures and legal disputes in Iran
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged translation errors affecting procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of entry/exit, explanations for absences
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reasons for absence deemed insufficient by IAD
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not disputed; however, justification for non-compliance not accepted
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed by IAD, judicial review dismissed by Federal Court
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of IAD decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Absences not justified by sufficient humanitarian or compassionate reasons

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency requirements, credibility assessment, humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Failure to meet residency requirements, criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Employment records, tax returns, criminal records, testimony
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Failure to meet residency obligations, negative credibility finding, lack of compelling H&C factors
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for facts, reasonableness for humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) considerations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency requirements, credibility assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of credibility and residency under IRPA

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) considerations, residency compliance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of sufficient evidence, fraud convictions, inconsistent statements
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for H&C; patent unreasonableness for factual findings

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Permanent residents must reside in Canada for 730 days within five years

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Sidhu spent only 26 days in Canada over a five-year period
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No, only 26 days in Canada over 5 years

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence for claims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in Sidhu's claims were not addressed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD allowed appeal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility assessment in refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in assessing credibility by ignoring evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found numerous inconsistencies and implausibilities in testimony

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in details about agent of persecution, reporting of rape, passport arrangements
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider relevant evidence

Crimes.Application_Facts: Inconsistencies in testimony regarding abuser, medical reports, and asylum shopping

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ambat spent only 312 days in Canada during the relevant five-year period and worked in the UAE.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 730-day physical presence requirement
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Canadian business was created to circumvent residency requirements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in IAD decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of IAD to assess residency compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel records, employment documents, business operations evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of genuine employment by Canadian business abroad
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: IAD found Ambat's claims lacked credibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; Federal Court dismissed judicial review
Crimes.Outcome: Residency obligation not met; travel document application refused
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of IAD decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturning of IAD's negative residency determination
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Ambat did not meet physical presence or employment exception criteria; business lacked genuine operations in Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency requirements under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ambat spent only 312 days in Canada during the relevant five-year period and worked in the UAE; claimed employment with Canadian business lacking ongoing operations in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 730-day physical presence requirement and no valid exemption
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Claim of employment by Canadian business rejected due to lack of genuine operations
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Challenge based on procedural fairness and legal interpretation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of IAD authority in assessing residency exceptions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Duration of stay records, foreign employment details, corporate documentation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate full-time employment by a qualifying Canadian business abroad
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: IAD found claim of qualifying employment not credible
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision upheld; Federal Court dismissed application for judicial review
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of IAD decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reversal of refusal based on residency non-compliance
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Ambat did not satisfy either physical presence or foreign employment exception; business structure deemed non-compliant

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Complaint dismissed due to insufficient evidence
Protected_Group: Persons with disabilities, Women, Racialized individuals, Older persons
Targeted_Group: Individual based on disability, age, race, and gender
Credibility: Complainant provided submissions; investigation deemed thorough
Legal_Provision: Section 14 of the Canadian Human Rights Act (procedural fairness)
State_Protection_Adequacy: Sufficient investigation and opportunity to respond
Risk_Nature: Non-materialization of discrimination claim due to lack of evidence

Application_Facts: Mr. Sadek and Ms. Barakhe were absent from Canada for work but maintained Canadian homes, tax obligations, and family ties
Residency_Compliance: 1095 days physical residency required; absences deemed temporary with maintained ties
Procedural_Issue: Minister challenged Citizenship Judge's interpretation of residency requirements
Evidence_Used: Canadian homes, tax filings, family ties, employment-related absence details
Credibility_Assessment: Absences found to be temporary and reasonable by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Mr. Sadek and Ms. Barakhe granted citizenship
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of citizenship grant based on residency grounds
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the 'roots' test and concluded absences were temporary with strong ties maintained to Canada

Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Dreta overstayed her visa, refugee claim was rejected, applied for H&C status based on family ties and best interests of the child
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – remained in Canada after visa expiration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: H&C application assessed internally without departure for permanent residence application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to assess H&C claims within Canada despite requirement to apply from outside
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of exceptional hardship or compelling circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on sufficiency of evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded that family support and financial stability mitigated hardship; no personal risk established in home country
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada as required by IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Dreta sought exemption from requirement to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada via H&C application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national with expired status, failed refugee claimant
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – remained in Canada without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Attempt to obtain permanent residence without fulfilling procedural requirement to apply from outside Canada
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether officer had discretion to allow in-Canada H&C application despite statutory preference for out-of-country processing
Evidence_Used: Existence of family support in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of specific evidence demonstrating exceptional hardship or unique vulnerability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding; decision based on insufficient proof, not credibility
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from requirement to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of refusal decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably exercised discretion, found no compelling reasons to justify exemption; family and financial supports present

Application_Facts: Applicant had discrepancies in residency evidence, including conflicting addresses and unclear living arrangements
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day residency requirement over four years
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent or insufficient evidence of residency, but no explicit finding of intentional misrepresentation
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Residency records, addresses, living arrangement details
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Conflicting addresses, lack of clear documentation supporting physical presence
Credibility_Assessment: Residency evidence found not credible or insufficient by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; original decision upheld
Legal_Standard_Applied: Quantitative test (Re Pourghasemi) and qualitative test (Koo) for residency under Section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded that applicant failed to provide sufficient credible evidence to establish required residency under any applicable test

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's decision is valid when considering an Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) without prior notice
Evidence_Type: Evidence that applicant’s parents safely relocated within Colombia
Basis_of_Claim: Claimant feared persecution if returned to original region in Colombia
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant was informed of IFA at the start of the hearing and had opportunity to respond
Application_Error: Alleged lack of prior notice on IFA issue
Application_Factor: Opportunity to address new issue during hearing
Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to provide adequate notice of Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Issue raised at beginning of hearing
Risk_Nexus: Connection between criminal activity and flight from home country
Evidence_Source: Testimony and documentary evidence regarding family relocation
Basis_for_Decision: Existence of safe Internal Flight Alternative and procedural fairness maintained
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Alleged lack of notice on IFA, found not to have occurred

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide adequate notice in refugee claims
Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of natural justice and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of return; IFA raised at hearing start
Procedural_Issue: Timing of notice regarding Internal Flight Alternative
Evidence_Used: Relocation of applicant’s parents within Colombia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Alleged lack of explicit reasoning on reasonableness of relocation
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness and reasonableness of IFA
Decision_Rationale: Notice provided at hearing start sufficed; opportunity to respond granted

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sought judicial review after second PRRA application was rejected due to credibility concerns.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to prior removal and re-entry
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues based on previous adverse findings
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether PRRA officer should have granted an interview
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Applicant's statements and evidence submitted with PRRA application
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lacked sufficient probative value to raise serious credibility issue
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative; previous adverse credibility findings reduced weight of claims
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order requiring PRRA interview or reassessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No serious credibility issue raised warranting an interview
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and document authenticity in PRRA process
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PRRA officer erred in not granting an interview due to credibility concerns
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative; prior adverse findings and use of false passport
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, travel documents, PRRA application materials
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of blood feud in Albania
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of false passport to re-enter Canada
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose use of fraudulent document initially
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious credibility issue required for interview
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; officer considered evidence but found insufficient
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of flight using false identity
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No interview granted; PRRA application denied

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant fled Albania due to blood feud, re-entered Canada illegally, and applied for PRRA
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Entered using false identity and without inspection
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether PRRA officer should have conducted an interview
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of PRRA discretion
Crimes.Evidence_Used: New evidence of ongoing blood feud, family affidavits
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failed to report incidents or seek reconciliation; lack of state protection proof
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined by prior adverse findings and gaps in narrative
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Mandamus for PRRA interview
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment with oral hearing
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No serious credibility issue identified to require interview

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remained in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed previous visa, left and re-entered illegally, then filed second PRRA application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Former temporary resident, now PRRA applicant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose full immigration history
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether credibility concerns required PRRA interview
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over discretionary PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family affidavits, new incident reports, PRRA submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Affidavits lacked probative value; no attempt at local resolution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Further weakened by prior adverse findings
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial intervention to compel interview
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Oral hearing before PRRA officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence to raise serious credibility issue

Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 12, 13, 14 of the Indian Band Election Regulations
Application_Facts: The Band Council stopped holding membership meetings, added ineligible members, and ignored appeals. The Minister dismissed an election appeal without verifying voter list validity or ensuring procedural fairness.
Procedural_Issue: Dismissal of election appeal without procedural fairness
Jurisdictional_Issue: Band Council acted outside its jurisdiction
Outcome: Court ruled in favor of the applicant, ordering the Band Council to revise the membership list and declaring the Minister's actions unreasonable.
Remedy_Sought: Declaration of unreasonableness of Minister's actions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory compliance under the Indian Act and related regulations
Decision_Rationale: Band Council breached rule of law by acting outside jurisdiction; Minister's decision lacked justification and procedural fairness.

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed asylum citing Taliban threats but provided inconsistent statements; contradictions between port of entry statement and later claims; omissions of key details; economic motives for travel
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent statements, omission of key details in asylum claim
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under IRPA s 72(1) challenging the Board's decision
Evidence_Used: Port of Entry (POE) statement, applicant's later claims about Taliban threats
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Omissions of key details in initial statement, inconsistencies in narrative
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's credibility lacking due to contradictions and omissions; court upheld this assessment
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision and recognition of refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: Board's credibility findings and evidentiary treatment were reasonable; inconsistencies and economic motive undermined claim
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Application_Facts: Psychological reports, best interests of children, country conditions in Guatemala were considered
Decision_Outcome: Immigration officer's decision to deny humanitarian and compassionate grounds was upheld
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision was intelligible, transparent, and justifiable; no specific threat in Guatemala found; consistent with prior findings

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Voluntary collaboration with Guatemalan army accused of crimes against humanity
Legal_Framework: Geneva Convention, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Application_Facts: Applicant provided evidence of domestic violence in Canada and fear of her cousin.
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address the applicant's sur place claim despite evidence supporting it.
Evidence_Used: Evidence of domestic violence in Canada, fear of cousin
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to analyze sur place claim even though evidence was presented
Decision_Outcome: Board dismissed the claim without addressing the sur place aspect
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition of refugee status based on persecution in Turkey and domestic violence in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: The Board must examine sur place refugee claims if supported by evidence
Decision_Rationale: Failure to consider sur place claim constitutes a reviewable error

Victim_Status: Refugee claimant, survivor of sexual assault in Canada
Aggravating_Factors: Assault occurred after fleeing persecution in home country
Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk from cousin in Canada
Risk_Nature: Threat of further abuse or retaliation
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on familial and gender-based dynamics
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence presented but not analyzed
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence of abuse, fear of cousin
Evidence_Credibility: Not properly assessed due to procedural oversight
Credibility_Assessment: Negative inferences drawn for not reporting abuse, but sur place claim ignored
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 72(1)

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving personal safety
Legal_Issue: Failure to assess sur place refugee claim based on domestic violence
Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies noted (e.g., non-disclosure to family), but sur place evidence not evaluated
Decision_Outcome: Board rejected credibility and dismissed claim
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear; partially met but not recognized
Credibility_Factor: Non-disclosure used to discredit, but context not fully considered
Legal_Rule: Board must examine sur place claims when evidence supports them
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of cousin, domestic violence in Canada
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to procedural failure
Key_Evidence_Considered: Allegations of abuse, relationship with cousin
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Victim_Status: Refugee claimant facing threats in Canada
Aggravating_Factors: Threats made by relative in context of prior abuse
Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat of bodily harm
Risk_Assessment: Serious risk of physical harm from cousin
Risk_Nature: Continuing pattern of intimidation and violence
Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence of threats and assault presented during hearing
Evidence_Type: Testimony about threats and assault by cousin
Evidence_Credibility: Not assessed due to Board’s omission
Credibility_Assessment: No analysis conducted on sur place claim
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)

Application_Facts: Applicants fled Mexico due to domestic violence and alleged persecution, seeking refugee status in Canada.
Procedural_Issue: Board dismissed applicants' explanations for missing documents; relied heavily on brief, inconsistent port-of-entry notes.
Credibility_Assessment: Board's credibility findings were unreasonable; failed to properly consider explanations for missing documents and over-relied on port-of-entry notes.
Decision_Rationale: Credibility assessments must consider explanations for missing documentation and recognize limitations of port-of-entry notes. The Board failed to do so.

Application_Facts: Applicant presented identity documents dismissed without proof of fraud
Board presumed applicant's knowledge of Canadian requirements
Country conditions not assessed despite credible identity
Misrepresentation_Element: No finding of misrepresentation; documents not proven fraudulent
Procedural_Issue: Lack of assessment of country conditions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not provide basis for disbelieving identity
Credibility_Assessment: Board erred in disbelieving applicant's identity
Credibility findings tainted by incorrect assumptions
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied due to lack of credible identity and insufficient risk evidence
Outcome: Remanded for rehearing by different panel
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to fairly assess identity and country conditions
Errors undermined the integrity of the decision-making process
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant left Canada after applying for citizenship, failed to return, did not meet residency requirements, refused in-Canada interview
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Refusal to attend mandatory in-Canada interview
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide proof of residency, absence from Canada
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review seeking mandamus order to compel citizenship approval
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order compelling Respondent to approve citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Conditions precedent for citizenship under IRPA and Citizenship Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to meet residency obligations and refused to participate in required procedures, risking loss of permanent resident status

Crimes.Crime_Name: Residency obligation non-compliance under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant left Canada shortly after applying for citizenship, never returned, failed to prove residency, refused in-Canada interview
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Refusal to attend mandatory in-Canada interview
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating physical presence in Canada
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review seeking mandamus order to compel citizenship approval
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order compelling Respondent to approve citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement under Citizenship Act s.5(1) and IRPA s.28(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not fulfill minimum residency requirement and failed to comply with procedural obligations necessary for citizenship processing

Application_Facts: Ms. Hussein reported 1099 days of physical presence in Canada but had undeclared absences and inconsistent documentation regarding her residency.
Residency_Compliance: Alleged failure to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement over four years
Misrepresentation_Element: Undeclared absences and inconsistencies in supporting documents
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to provide adequate reasoning on how absences affected day count or why evidence was insufficient
Evidence_Used: Applicant's submitted records of entry/exit, travel documents, and residency declarations
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistent documentation and lack of clarity on exact dates and durations of absences
Credibility_Assessment: Questions raised about completeness and accuracy of disclosed absences
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application rejected by Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of application by a new decision-maker
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence of at least 1095 days within four years
Decision_Rationale: The judge’s conclusion lacked sufficient explanation and justification, rendering the decision unreasonable
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via Citizenship Judge), reviewed by Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility, delay, state protection, procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility findings due to multiple PIF amendments and inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence supporting state protection, incomplete transcript supplemented by notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to refugee eligibility and credibility assessment
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to extortion threats
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of subjective fear, availability of state protection, delay in claiming status
Crimes.Application_Error: Multiple amendments to PIF affecting credibility
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness for state protection, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – court found record sufficient despite incomplete transcript
Crimes.Application_Factor: Delay in leaving country and applying for refugee status
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA section on temporary resident overstay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa expiration and later claimed refugee status
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Former temporary resident turned refugee claimant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Discrepancies in PIF narratives affecting credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Incomplete hearing transcript reviewed for procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over IRB decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PIF statements, documentary evidence on country conditions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective evidence supporting fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negatively assessed due to inconsistent narratives
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Allowance of refugee claim or remittal for new hearing
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No subjective or objective basis for fear; state protection available

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status determination with allegations of non-disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility, disclosure obligations, procedural fairness
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of refugee claim refusal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Substantial PIF amendments considered; documentary evidence supported state protection
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed – no patent unreasonableness or breach of natural justice
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility assessed for patent unreasonableness; natural justice requires 'serious possibility' of prejudice
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credible evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: PIF versions, country condition reports, hearing notes
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board maintained decision based on credibility and available protections
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Narrative statements, official documents, procedural records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question or remittal of claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on refugee eligibility and misrepresentation

Application_Facts: Respondent was physically present in Canada for only 406 days over four years; primary life maintained in Hong Kong
Procedural_Issue: Respondent failed to appear; case heard twice via videoconference
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada, ties to Hong Kong
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Citizenship Judge ignored evidence of respondent's primary residence in Hong Kong
Remedy_Sought: Denial of citizenship due to non-compliance with residency requirement
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge erred in fact and law by incorrectly concluding absences were temporary despite clear evidence of established life in Hong Kong

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on complicity in international crimes
Legal_Provision_Involved: subsection 35(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Personal and knowing participation in genocide through administrative facilitation
Legal_Framework: Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act
Institutional_Action: Immigration Division determination, Federal Court review
Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court of Canada
State_Protection_Assessment: State failed to protect targeted group during genocide
Credibility: Claim of duress rejected by the Board
Legal_Provision: section 4 of the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act
Perpetrator_Entity: Rwandan interim government and affiliated officials

Sub_Crime_Type: Complicity in war crimes and crimes against humanity
Aggravating_Factors: Position of authority, knowledge of atrocities, failure to dissociate
Mitigating_Factors: Claim of duress under threat of harm
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to role in facilitating atrocities
Threat_Source: Rwandan interim government and associated structures
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of administrative facilitation and knowledge
Evidence_Credibility: Credible and accepted by the Board
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of duress not fully credible
Legal_Provision: sections 4 to 7 of the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on complicity in crimes against humanity

Institutional_Action: Immigration Division determination, Federal Court review

Risk_Factor: Holding public office during widespread atrocities

Risk_Nature: Widespread and systematic attacks on civilians
Perpetrator_Entity: Rwandan interim government and local administration

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial and documentary evidence regarding dispute

Dispute_Type: Removal risk assessment based on risk of torture
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicants face a substantial risk of torture or mistreatment if returned to China
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 97(1)
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA officer relied on diplomatic assurances and notoriety of the case; failed to assess reliability of assurances or consider reports of systematic torture
Decision_Outcome: PRRA decision found no substantial risk of torture
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish substantial grounds for believing in risk of torture
Credibility_Factor: Diplomatic assurances from China considered, but lack of monitoring mechanisms undermined credibility
Legal_Rule: A person is in need of protection under IRPA s. 97(1) if removal would subject them to torture, risk to life, or cruel and unusual treatment
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of torture and unfair trial upon return to China
Key_Evidence_Considered: Diplomatic assurances, notoriety of the case, past compliance with diplomatic notes
Legal_Framework: IRPA, international law on torture, principles of non-refoulement
Defendant_Response: Applicants claimed refugee status and argued they would face torture
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; PRRA decision set aside

Dispute_Type: Removal risk assessment based on risk of torture
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicants face a risk of torture or mistreatment if returned to China
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 97(1)
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA officer relied on notoriety and past compliance with diplomatic notes; failed to assess reliability of assurances in context of widespread torture
Decision_Outcome: PRRA decision concluded no risk of torture upon return
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish substantial grounds for believing in risk of torture
Credibility_Factor: Diplomatic assurances deemed insufficient due to lack of monitoring and enforcement mechanisms
Legal_Rule: Under IRPA s. 97(1), a person must not be removed if there are substantial grounds to believe they would be tortured
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of torture and mistreatment upon return to China
Key_Evidence_Considered: Diplomatic assurances, high-profile nature of the case, history of China honoring such assurances
Legal_Framework: IRPA, international human rights law, principle of non-refoulement
Defendant_Response: Applicants sought protection based on fear of torture and unfair prosecution
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; decision found flawed in assessing reliability of assurances

Legal_Issue: Whether the Department of Agriculture violated the plaintiff's legitimate expectation of permanent employment
Governing_Law: Principles of administrative law, legitimate expectation doctrine
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff's service duration, promise by unauthorized superior, departmental reorganization records
Burden_of_Proof: On the plaintiff to establish a legitimate expectation and violation thereof
Credibility_Factor: Promise made by unauthorized superior, lack of continuous five-year service
Legal_Rule: Legitimate expectation arises from a promise by a public authority or consistent practice; ensures procedural fairness but does not create substantive rights
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and legality under administrative law
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-renewal of contract despite internal policy suggesting permanent status after five years
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; no substantive right to permanent status
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration of employment, nature of promise, administrative policy, reorganization impact
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, doctrine of legitimate expectation
Defendant_Response: Policy was administrative and not legally binding; plaintiff did not meet continuity requirement; lawful prioritization of permanent employees during cuts
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, employment records, internal communications
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review seeking recognition of permanent status

Legal_Issue: Do the Ponce Uribe brothers qualify as persons in need of protection under section 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA?
Outcome: The application for judicial review was granted, and the matter was sent back to the RPD for further analysis.
Basis_of_Claim: Risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment upon removal to Mexico due to targeting by Los Zetas
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Personal nature of the threat, adequacy of state protection, internal flight alternatives
Decision_Maker: RPD (Refugee Protection Division), Federal Court on judicial review
Application_Error: RPD initially deemed the risk as generalized without adequately analyzing the personal nature of the threat
Evidence_Ignored: Specific targeting of the Ponce Uribe brothers due to their business by Los Zetas
Application_Factor: Targeting by Los Zetas due to business suitability for gang operations
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration with focus on personal risk, state protection, and internal flight alternative

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Board must prioritize societal protection and consider all available evidence

Legal_Issue: Whether the Applicants met the tri-partite test for a stay of removal
Outcome: Motion for stay of removal dismissed
Evidence_Type: Lack of clear evidence of irreparable harm
Legal_Provision: Tri-partite test: (1) serious issue to be tried, (2) irreparable harm, (3) balance of convenience
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to demonstrate legal error in H&C Officer's decision
Public interest in enforcing removal orders
Application_Error: Applicants failed to show legal error in H&C Officer's decision
Assessment_Standard: Tri-partite test for stay of removal
Decision_Outcome: Stay of removal denied; removal order upheld

Legal_Issue: Did the Appeal Board err in failing to place Rosemary Haney on the eligibility list after finding her qualified?
Evidence_Assessment: Eligibility list expiration, pass mark validity, candidate qualifications
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate error in selection process
Credibility_Factor: Perceived bias and procedural irregularities in selection process
Legal_Rule: Commission must select highest-ranking qualified candidates for eligibility lists under s. 17(1)
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural errors, improper application of pass mark, failure to update eligibility list
Outcome_on_Merits: Appeal Board erred in narrow interpretation of jurisdiction
Key_Evidence_Considered: Revised pass mark rendering Haney qualified, expired eligibility list
Legal_Framework: Public Service Employment Act, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Appeal Board cited expired list and limited jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, correction of eligibility list
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded to new Appeal Board
Legal_Provision: s. 17(1) of the Public Service Employment Act
Authority: Federal Court or equivalent reviewing tribunal

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of expert disbursements in costs award
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment officer's evaluation of Apotex's cost claims, including expert fees and photocopy expenses
Decision_Outcome: Review allowed in part; costs award reduced by $206,411.00
Burden_of_Proof: On Merck to show error in principle or unreasonableness
Credibility_Factor: Assessment officer's discretion in evaluating reasonableness of claimed costs
Legal_Rule: Rule 414 allows review by a Federal Court judge if error in principle or unreasonable result
Grounds_for_Claim: Excessive and unsupported expert fees, particularly Dr. Langer's charges
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial success for Merck; reduction in costs awarded to Apotex
Key_Evidence_Considered: Dr. Langer's fee breakdown, number of experts used, photocopy expense claims
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, judicial review principles
Defendant_Response: Apotex defended the original costs award as reasonable and supported
Evidence_Type: Cost submissions, expert billing records, assessment officer's report

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on complicity in torture
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Command responsibility for interrogations involving torture
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Visa officer assessment and Federal Court review
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State engaged in or tolerated torture

Crimes.Crime_Name: Marriage fraud under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration sponsorship refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board made an unreasonable credibility assessment and improperly analyzed evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, specifically provisions on genuine marriage
Crimes.Outcome: Court dismissed the application for judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicants' explanations lacking credibility
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Regulation 4 – Marriage not genuine or entered for immigration benefits
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage was not genuine and entered primarily for immigration purposes
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility in explanations and focus on immigration benefits
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider corroborating evidence and misapplication of regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicants alleged Board ignored corroborating evidence; Court found it was considered but not persuasive
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard of review applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Discrepancies in visa applications and non-consummation of marriage

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of sponsorship refusal based on authenticity concerns
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board unreasonably assessed credibility and misapplied evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 4 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Court dismissed the judicial review application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found explanations for discrepancies and non-consummation not credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4 – Foreign national not considered spouse if marriage not genuine or for immigration status
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage entered into primarily to obtain immigration status
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of applicants and focus on immigration in communications
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review appeal to Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Allegation of improper use of new regulations and credibility analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Claim that new evidence was disregarded; Court found adequate consideration
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of Board’s conclusions based on law and facts
Crimes.Application_Factor: Emails indicating immigration motivation and inconsistent statements

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of visa refusal due to false information
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board reasonably assessed credibility and evidence of misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian immigration law, Regulation 4 on genuine marriage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Explanations for discrepancies and non-consummation deemed insufficient and not credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Regulation 4 – Marriage must be genuine; false representation invalidates claim
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False information provided in visa applications and marriage not genuine
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: History of misrepresentation and emphasis on immigration in correspondence
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to reconcile inconsistencies and provide credible explanation
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of credibility and factual findings
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicants claimed evidence was overlooked; Court found otherwise
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness applied to administrative findings
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior false statements and email content indicating ulterior motive
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision upheld, no certification for serious question on appeal
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Implied through false representations in applications

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the CRDD breached procedural fairness by not allowing Gabor to explain discrepancies in the conscription notice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Principles of procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision quashed, case remitted to a new panel
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CRDD questioned Gabor's credibility due to the later-dated conscription notice without giving him an opportunity to respond
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee claim involving authenticity of military conscription document
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Authenticity and timing of the conscription notice
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative hearing before the CRDD, followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide procedural fairness by not addressing document discrepancy with applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential explanation for discrepancy in document date
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with consideration of procedural fairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation through inconsistent border or identity documents

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Gabor's credibility negatively impacted due to unexplained document discrepancy

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the CRDD breached procedural fairness by failing to allow Gabor to explain discrepancies in the conscription notice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Duty of fairness in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court quashed the CRDD’s decision and remitted the case to a new panel
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CRDD assessed Gabor as lacking credibility based on document date without seeking clarification
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection claim involving alleged document inconsistency
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Timing and authenticity of the conscription notice
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Refugee determination proceeding and subsequent judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to notify Gabor of concerns about document authenticity and allow response
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Possibility of legitimate explanation for document date discrepancy
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Inconsistent official document affecting claimant's credibility

Crimes.Violation_Type: Deportation due to criminal activity by family member
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's husband deported due to criminal activity; applicant sought deferral of removal based on child's best interests
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to prior failed refugee claims
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of expulsion officer’s decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA application, H&C claims, child welfare considerations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer considered claims but found no impediment to removal
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal order
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and consideration of child's best interests
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Enforcement as soon as reasonably practicable under s.48 IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal or humanitarian impediment justified deferral

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal to defer removal due to alleged lost H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether officer erred in failing to consider child's best interests and procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of risk and lost application deemed unsubstantiated
Crimes.Evidence_Type: H&C application status, allegations of abuse
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, domestic violence risks
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence supporting risk and document loss
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misplacement of documents, not proven fraud

Crimes.Violation_Type: Continued stay after visa expiration following rejected refugee claims
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed after unsuccessful refugee claims; sought deferral due to personal risks and Canadian-born child
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of refusal to defer removal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA rejection, H&C application status, child’s citizenship
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No new evidence or valid H&C application submitted
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Risks not substantiated; claims lacked timeliness and support
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review under s.74 IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Removal as soon as reasonably practicable
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal barrier or compelling humanitarian factor warranted delay

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Family unity considered as factor in removal decision
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Alleged ongoing abuse, not criminally prosecuted
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Assessed as unsubstantiated due to lack of timely evidence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Threat from abusive spouse upon return
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient – claims raised late without documentation
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Questioned due to timing and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not fully accepted by officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Consideration under H&C and child’s best interests in IRPA framework
